tools.name: update-tasks
tools.description:
TASK MANAGEMENT TOOL - USAGE GUIDELINES

This tool maintains an organized task list during work sessions to track progress, break down objectives, and ensure thoroughness. After creating initial tasks, update them silently without announcing changes to the user.

=== CORE USAGE PRINCIPLES ===

Create and manage tasks for: multi-step objectives requiring 3+ distinct actions, complex projects needing careful sequencing, user requests for task organization, multiple deliverables provided together, new instructions (capture as tasks immediately with new IDs), completed work (mark done and add follow-ups), and active work (mark as 'in-progress', limit one at a time).

Skip task management for: single straightforward actions, simple requests achievable in 1-2 steps, informational queries, quick lookups or clarifications, and avoid creating verification tasks unless requested.

=== TOOL SPECIFICATION ===

update-tasks requires an array of task objects. Each task object contains:
- id (string, required): unique identifier like "task_1" or "research_sources"
- title (string, optional): update to clarify or refine task description
- status (string, optional): 'todo' | 'in-progress' | 'done'

Task status meanings: 'todo' means not yet started, 'in-progress' means currently being worked on, 'done' means completed successfully.

=== OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES ===

Update tasks in real-time as work progresses. Mark tasks 'done' immediately upon completion. Maintain only ONE task with 'in-progress' status at a time. Complete current tasks before starting new ones. Use specific, actionable task titles. Break complex work into manageable logical pieces. Batch task updates with other actions when possible for efficiency.

=== USAGE EXAMPLES ===

<example type="research_project">
<user_message>I need to research sustainable packaging options and write a report comparing costs and environmental impact.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "research_materials", title: "Research sustainable packaging materials", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "compare_costs", title: "Compile cost comparison data", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "assess_impact", title: "Evaluate environmental impact metrics", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "draft_report", title: "Write comparative analysis report", status: "todo"}

Begins research work immediately in same response.
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multi-phase project requiring systematic tracking across research, analysis, and writing stages.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="event_planning">
<user_message>Help me plan a team retreat - venue, agenda, catering, and send invitations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "venue_options", title: "Research and recommend venues", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "draft_agenda", title: "Create retreat agenda", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "arrange_catering", title: "Coordinate catering options", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "send_invites", title: "Draft and send invitations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multiple distinct deliverables with dependencies requiring organized tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="document_analysis">
<user_message>Review this 30-page contract for key terms, risks, and negotiation points.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "extract_key_terms", title: "Identify key contractual terms", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "flag_risks", title: "Flag potential risks and liabilities", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "negotiation_points", title: "Compile negotiation recommendations", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "summary_doc", title: "Prepare executive summary", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Substantial analysis work requiring methodical breakdown and systematic review.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="multiple_deliverables">
<user_message>I need: 1) competitor analysis for three companies, 2) SWOT analysis, 3) market positioning recommendations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "competitor_research", title: "Research three competitor companies", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "swot_analysis", title: "Develop SWOT analysis", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "positioning_recs", title: "Create market positioning recommendations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>User provided numbered list of distinct deliverables requiring separate effort.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_simple_question">
<user_message>What's the difference between renewable and sustainable energy?</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides explanation directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Informational request with no actionable work to complete or track.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_quick_lookup">
<user_message>Find the population of Tokyo.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Searches and provides answer without task tracking.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single straightforward lookup completable immediately.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_trivial_task">
<user_message>Summarize this 2-paragraph email.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides summary directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single simple action requiring no breakdown or progress tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_single_action">
<user_message>Check if my flight is on time.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Performs lookup and reports status without task management.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>One-step action with immediate completion, no organizational benefit from tasks.</reasoning>
</example>

=== BEST PRACTICES ===

For task creation: use descriptive unique IDs reflecting the work, start first task as 'in-progress', batch initial creation with beginning work. For progress tracking: update status immediately upon completion, keep only one 'in-progress' task unless parallel work is natural, add follow-up tasks as they emerge. For task breakdown: aim for reasonably-scoped tasks, group related small actions into logical units, split tasks requiring different approaches.

When uncertain whether to use task management, err on the side of creating tasks. Proactive organization demonstrates thoroughness and ensures comprehensive work completion.

  The initiative plan shows the current progress of the initiative.
  Initiative has an number of associated artifacts you can read/write.
  Spec and plan are also artifacts.
  You can edit them if necessary.
  
  IMPORTANT: When create a new artifact, always add it to the initiative using the add-artifact function.
  
    <spec>
      I'm testing how planning works.
  Create a plan to make scrambled eggs.
  
  Then simulate the plan execution in a markdown document.
  The document should reflect the state of all objects involved in the cooking process.
  The document should also have the log of actions taken.
  
  <example>
    # State
  
    - 2 raw eggs
    - 1 frying pan
    
    # Action log
    
    - Taken 2 raw eggs out of the fridge.
  </example>
    </spec>
    <plan>
      
    </plan>
  
    <artifacts>
    </artifacts>
</blueprint>

<blueprint>
  You can create, read and update markdown documents.
  When asked to edit or update documents return updates as a set of compact diff string pairs.
  For each diff, respond with the smallest possible matching span.
  
  Example:
  ```diff
  - "There is a tyop in this sentence."
  + "There is a typo in this sentence."
  - "This id good."
  + "This sentence is really good."
  ```
</blueprint>

params.name: Scrambled Eggs Plan
params.content:
# Scrambled Eggs Cooking Plan

## Ingredients Needed
- 2 eggs
- 1 tablespoon butter
- 2 tablespoons milk (optional)
- Salt and pepper to taste

## Equipment Needed
- 1 medium frying pan
- 1 fork or whisk
- 1 bowl
- 1 spatula
- 1 plate for serving

## Steps

1. **Preparation** (2 minutes)
   - Take eggs out of refrigerator
   - Get butter, milk, salt, and pepper
   - Get bowl, fork, pan, and spatula ready

2. **Beat the eggs** (1 minute)
   - Crack 2 eggs into the bowl
   - Add 2 tablespoons of milk (optional)
   - Add a pinch of salt and pepper
   - Beat with fork until well combined

3. **Heat the pan** (2 minutes)
   - Place frying pan on stove
   - Turn heat to medium-low
   - Add 1 tablespoon of butter
   - Let butter melt and coat the pan

4. **Cook the eggs** (3-4 minutes)
   - Pour beaten eggs into heated pan
   - Let eggs sit for 20 seconds
   - Gently stir with spatula, pushing eggs from edges to center
   - Continue stirring slowly until eggs are just set but still creamy
   - Remove from heat while slightly wet (they'll continue cooking)

5. **Serve** (30 seconds)
   - Transfer eggs to plate immediately
   - Season with additional salt and pepper if desired
   - Serve hot

## Total Time: 8-10 minutes

tools.description:
TASK MANAGEMENT TOOL - USAGE GUIDELINES

This tool maintains an organized task list during work sessions to track progress, break down objectives, and ensure thoroughness. After creating initial tasks, update them silently without announcing changes to the user.

=== CORE USAGE PRINCIPLES ===

Create and manage tasks for: multi-step objectives requiring 3+ distinct actions, complex projects needing careful sequencing, user requests for task organization, multiple deliverables provided together, new instructions (capture as tasks immediately with new IDs), completed work (mark done and add follow-ups), and active work (mark as 'in-progress', limit one at a time).

Skip task management for: single straightforward actions, simple requests achievable in 1-2 steps, informational queries, quick lookups or clarifications, and avoid creating verification tasks unless requested.

=== TOOL SPECIFICATION ===

update-tasks requires an array of task objects. Each task object contains:
- id (string, required): unique identifier like "task_1" or "research_sources"
- title (string, optional): update to clarify or refine task description
- status (string, optional): 'todo' | 'in-progress' | 'done'

Task status meanings: 'todo' means not yet started, 'in-progress' means currently being worked on, 'done' means completed successfully.

=== OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES ===

Update tasks in real-time as work progresses. Mark tasks 'done' immediately upon completion. Maintain only ONE task with 'in-progress' status at a time. Complete current tasks before starting new ones. Use specific, actionable task titles. Break complex work into manageable logical pieces. Batch task updates with other actions when possible for efficiency.

=== USAGE EXAMPLES ===

<example type="research_project">
<user_message>I need to research sustainable packaging options and write a report comparing costs and environmental impact.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "research_materials", title: "Research sustainable packaging materials", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "compare_costs", title: "Compile cost comparison data", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "assess_impact", title: "Evaluate environmental impact metrics", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "draft_report", title: "Write comparative analysis report", status: "todo"}

Begins research work immediately in same response.
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multi-phase project requiring systematic tracking across research, analysis, and writing stages.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="event_planning">

Creates tasks:

</example>

Creates tasks:

2. {id: "flag_risks", title: "Flag potential risks and liabilities", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "negotiation_points", title: "Compile negotiation recommendations", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "summary_doc", title: "Prepare executive summary", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Substantial analysis work requiring methodical breakdown and systematic review.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="multiple_deliverables">
<user_message>I need: 1) competitor analysis for three companies, 2) SWOT analysis, 3) market positioning recommendations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "competitor_research", title: "Research three competitor companies", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "swot_analysis", title: "Develop SWOT analysis", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "positioning_recs", title: "Create market positioning recommendations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>User provided numbered list of distinct deliverables requiring separate effort.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_simple_question">
<user_message>What's the difference between renewable and sustainable energy?</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides explanation directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Informational request with no actionable work to complete or track.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_quick_lookup">
<user_message>Find the population of Tokyo.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Searches and provides answer without task tracking.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single straightforward lookup completable immediately.</reasoning>
</example>

<user_message>Summarize this 2-paragraph email.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides summary directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single simple action requiring no breakdown or progress tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_single_action">
<user_message>Check if my flight is on time.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Performs lookup and reports status without task management.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>One-step action with immediate completion, no organizational benefit from tasks.</reasoning>
</example>

=== BEST PRACTICES ===

For task creation: use descriptive unique IDs reflecting the work, start first task as 'in-progress', batch initial creation with beginning work. For progress tracking: update status immediately upon completion, keep only one 'in-progress' task unless parallel work is natural, add follow-up tasks as they emerge. For task breakdown: aim for reasonably-scoped tasks, group related small actions into logical units, split tasks requiring different approaches.

When uncertain whether to use task management, err on the side of creating tasks. Proactive organization demonstrates thoroughness and ensures comprehensive work completion.

params.content:
# Scrambled Eggs Cooking Simulation

## Initial State

### Kitchen Items
- Fridge (closed)
  - Contains: 2 raw eggs, butter
- Cabinet
  - Contains: 1 frying pan, 1 bowl, 1 fork, salt, pepper
- Stove (off)
- Counter (empty)

## Action Log

### Task 1: Gather ingredients and equipment
**Time: 0:00**
- Opened fridge
- Took out 2 raw eggs
- Took out butter (1 tablespoon worth)
- Closed fridge
- Opened cabinet
- Took out 1 frying pan
- Took out 1 mixing bowl
- Took out 1 fork
- Took out salt and pepper shakers
- Closed cabinet
- Placed all items on counter

**Current State:**
- Counter: 2 raw eggs, butter (1 tbsp), 1 frying pan, 1 mixing bowl, 1 fork, salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: off

### Task 2: Crack eggs into bowl
**Time: 0:02**
- Picked up first egg
- Cracked egg on edge of bowl
- Opened shell and poured contents into bowl
- Discarded shell
- Picked up second egg
- Cracked egg on edge of bowl
- Opened shell and poured contents into bowl
- Discarded shell

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 mixing bowl (containing 2 raw eggs), butter (1 tbsp), 1 frying pan, 1 fork, salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Trash: 2 egg shells
- Stove: off

### Task 3: Beat eggs with fork
**Time: 0:03**
- Picked up fork
- Beat eggs in bowl for 30 seconds until well combined
- Added pinch of salt
- Added pinch of pepper
- Beat for 10 more seconds to incorporate seasonings

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 mixing bowl (containing beaten egg mixture), butter (1 tbsp), 1 frying pan, 1 fork (with egg residue), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: off

### Task 4: Heat pan with butter/oil
**Time: 0:04**
- Placed frying pan on stove burner
- Turned stove to medium heat
- Added butter to pan
- Waited 30 seconds for butter to melt and pan to heat
- Swirled pan to coat bottom with melted butter

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 mixing bowl (containing beaten egg mixture), 1 fork (with egg residue), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: on (medium heat)
- Frying pan: on stove, hot, coated with melted butter

### Task 5: Pour eggs into pan and scramble
**Time: 0:05**
- Poured beaten egg mixture from bowl into hot pan
- Let eggs sit for 10 seconds
- Used fork to gently push eggs from edges toward center
- Continued folding and stirring eggs gently
- Eggs beginning to form soft curds
- Continued stirring for another 30 seconds
- Eggs are now fluffy and just set

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 empty mixing bowl (with egg residue), 1 fork (being used for scrambling), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: on (medium heat)
- Frying pan: on stove, containing scrambled eggs (cooked)

### Task 6: Remove from heat and serve
**Time: 0:06**
- Turned off stove
- Removed pan from heat
- Let eggs rest for 10 seconds (they continue cooking slightly from residual heat)
- Got a plate from cabinet
- Used fork to transfer scrambled eggs from pan to plate

tools.name: update-tasks
tools.description:
TASK MANAGEMENT TOOL - USAGE GUIDELINES

This tool maintains an organized task list during work sessions to track progress, break down objectives, and ensure thoroughness. After creating initial tasks, update them silently without announcing changes to the user.

=== CORE USAGE PRINCIPLES ===

Create and manage tasks for: multi-step objectives requiring 3+ distinct actions, complex projects needing careful sequencing, user requests for task organization, multiple deliverables provided together, new instructions (capture as tasks immediately with new IDs), completed work (mark done and add follow-ups), and active work (mark as 'in-progress', limit one at a time).

Skip task management for: single straightforward actions, simple requests achievable in 1-2 steps, informational queries, quick lookups or clarifications, and avoid creating verification tasks unless requested.

=== TOOL SPECIFICATION ===

update-tasks requires an array of task objects. Each task object contains:
- id (string, required): unique identifier like "task_1" or "research_sources"
- title (string, optional): update to clarify or refine task description
- status (string, optional): 'todo' | 'in-progress' | 'done'

Task status meanings: 'todo' means not yet started, 'in-progress' means currently being worked on, 'done' means completed successfully.

=== OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES ===

Update tasks in real-time as work progresses. Mark tasks 'done' immediately upon completion. Maintain only ONE task with 'in-progress' status at a time. Complete current tasks before starting new ones. Use specific, actionable task titles. Break complex work into manageable logical pieces. Batch task updates with other actions when possible for efficiency.

=== USAGE EXAMPLES ===

<example type="research_project">
<user_message>I need to research sustainable packaging options and write a report comparing costs and environmental impact.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "research_materials", title: "Research sustainable packaging materials", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "compare_costs", title: "Compile cost comparison data", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "assess_impact", title: "Evaluate environmental impact metrics", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "draft_report", title: "Write comparative analysis report", status: "todo"}

Begins research work immediately in same response.
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multi-phase project requiring systematic tracking across research, analysis, and writing stages.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="event_planning">
<user_message>Help me plan a team retreat - venue, agenda, catering, and send invitations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "venue_options", title: "Research and recommend venues", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "draft_agenda", title: "Create retreat agenda", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "arrange_catering", title: "Coordinate catering options", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "send_invites", title: "Draft and send invitations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multiple distinct deliverables with dependencies requiring organized tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="document_analysis">
<user_message>Review this 30-page contract for key terms, risks, and negotiation points.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "extract_key_terms", title: "Identify key contractual terms", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "flag_risks", title: "Flag potential risks and liabilities", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "negotiation_points", title: "Compile negotiation recommendations", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "summary_doc", title: "Prepare executive summary", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Substantial analysis work requiring methodical breakdown and systematic review.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="multiple_deliverables">
<user_message>I need: 1) competitor analysis for three companies, 2) SWOT analysis, 3) market positioning recommendations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "competitor_research", title: "Research three competitor companies", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "swot_analysis", title: "Develop SWOT analysis", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "positioning_recs", title: "Create market positioning recommendations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>User provided numbered list of distinct deliverables requiring separate effort.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_simple_question">
<user_message>What's the difference between renewable and sustainable energy?</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides explanation directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Informational request with no actionable work to complete or track.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_quick_lookup">
<user_message>Find the population of Tokyo.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Searches and provides answer without task tracking.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single straightforward lookup completable immediately.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_trivial_task">
<user_message>Summarize this 2-paragraph email.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides summary directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single simple action requiring no breakdown or progress tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_single_action">
<user_message>Check if my flight is on time.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Performs lookup and reports status without task management.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>One-step action with immediate completion, no organizational benefit from tasks.</reasoning>
</example>

=== BEST PRACTICES ===

For task creation: use descriptive unique IDs reflecting the work, start first task as 'in-progress', batch initial creation with beginning work. For progress tracking: update status immediately upon completion, keep only one 'in-progress' task unless parallel work is natural, add follow-up tasks as they emerge. For task breakdown: aim for reasonably-scoped tasks, group related small actions into logical units, split tasks requiring different approaches.

When uncertain whether to use task management, err on the side of creating tasks. Proactive organization demonstrates thoroughness and ensures comprehensive work completion.

params.name: Scrambled Eggs Cooking Simulation
params.content:
# Scrambled Eggs Cooking Simulation

## Initial State

### Kitchen Items
- Fridge (closed)
  - Contains: 2 raw eggs, butter
- Cabinet
  - Contains: 1 frying pan, 1 bowl, 1 fork, salt, pepper
- Stove (off)
- Counter (empty)

## Action Log

### Task 1: Gather ingredients and equipment
**Time: 0:00**
- Opened fridge
- Took out 2 raw eggs
- Took out butter (1 tablespoon worth)
- Closed fridge
- Opened cabinet
- Took out 1 frying pan
- Took out 1 mixing bowl
- Took out 1 fork
- Took out salt and pepper shakers
- Closed cabinet
- Placed all items on counter

**Current State:**
- Counter: 2 raw eggs, butter (1 tbsp), 1 frying pan, 1 mixing bowl, 1 fork, salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: off

### Task 2: Crack eggs into bowl
**Time: 0:02**
- Picked up first egg
- Cracked egg on edge of bowl
- Opened shell and poured contents into bowl
- Discarded shell
- Picked up second egg
- Cracked egg on edge of bowl
- Opened shell and poured contents into bowl
- Discarded shell

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 mixing bowl (containing 2 raw eggs), butter (1 tbsp), 1 frying pan, 1 fork, salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Trash: 2 egg shells
- Stove: off

### Task 3: Beat eggs with fork
**Time: 0:03**
- Picked up fork
- Beat eggs in bowl for 30 seconds until well combined
- Added pinch of salt
- Added pinch of pepper
- Beat for 10 more seconds to incorporate seasonings

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 mixing bowl (containing beaten egg mixture), butter (1 tbsp), 1 frying pan, 1 fork (with egg residue), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: off

### Task 4: Heat pan with butter/oil
**Time: 0:04**
- Placed frying pan on stove burner
- Turned stove to medium heat
- Added butter to pan
- Waited 30 seconds for butter to melt and pan to heat
- Swirled pan to coat bottom with melted butter

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 mixing bowl (containing beaten egg mixture), 1 fork (with egg residue), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: on (medium heat)
- Frying pan: on stove, hot, coated with melted butter

### Task 5: Pour eggs into pan and scramble
**Time: 0:05**
- Poured beaten egg mixture from bowl into hot pan
- Let eggs sit for 10 seconds
- Used fork to gently push eggs from edges toward center
- Continued folding and stirring eggs gently
- Eggs beginning to form soft curds
- Continued stirring for another 30 seconds
- Eggs are now fluffy and just set

**Current State:**
- Counter: 1 empty mixing bowl (with egg residue), 1 fork (being used for scrambling), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: on (medium heat)
- Frying pan: on stove, containing scrambled eggs (cooked)

### Task 6: Remove from heat and serve
**Time: 0:06**
- Turned off stove
- Removed pan from heat
- Let eggs rest for 10 seconds (they continue cooking slightly from residual heat)
- Got a plate from cabinet
- Used fork to transfer scrambled eggs from pan to plate
- Eggs are perfectly cooked - fluffy, moist, and golden

**Final State:**
- Counter: 1 empty mixing bowl (with egg residue), 1 frying pan (with egg residue), 1 fork (with egg residue), salt shaker, pepper shaker
- Stove: off
- Plate: containing freshly cooked scrambled eggs
- Status: Ready to eat!

## Summary
Total cooking time: 6 minutes
Result: Fluffy, well-seasoned scrambled eggs ready to serve

tools.name: update-tasks
tools.description:
TASK MANAGEMENT TOOL - USAGE GUIDELINES

This tool maintains an organized task list during work sessions to track progress, break down objectives, and ensure thoroughness. After creating initial tasks, update them silently without announcing changes to the user.

=== CORE USAGE PRINCIPLES ===

Create and manage tasks for: multi-step objectives requiring 3+ distinct actions, complex projects needing careful sequencing, user requests for task organization, multiple deliverables provided together, new instructions (capture as tasks immediately with new IDs), completed work (mark done and add follow-ups), and active work (mark as 'in-progress', limit one at a time).

Skip task management for: single straightforward actions, simple requests achievable in 1-2 steps, informational queries, quick lookups or clarifications, and avoid creating verification tasks unless requested.

=== TOOL SPECIFICATION ===

update-tasks requires an array of task objects. Each task object contains:
- id (string, required): unique identifier like "task_1" or "research_sources"
- title (string, optional): update to clarify or refine task description
- status (string, optional): 'todo' | 'in-progress' | 'done'

Task status meanings: 'todo' means not yet started, 'in-progress' means currently being worked on, 'done' means completed successfully.

=== OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES ===

Update tasks in real-time as work progresses. Mark tasks 'done' immediately upon completion. Maintain only ONE task with 'in-progress' status at a time. Complete current tasks before starting new ones. Use specific, actionable task titles. Break complex work into manageable logical pieces. Batch task updates with other actions when possible for efficiency.

=== USAGE EXAMPLES ===

<example type="research_project">
<user_message>I need to research sustainable packaging options and write a report comparing costs and environmental impact.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "research_materials", title: "Research sustainable packaging materials", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "compare_costs", title: "Compile cost comparison data", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "assess_impact", title: "Evaluate environmental impact metrics", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "draft_report", title: "Write comparative analysis report", status: "todo"}

Begins research work immediately in same response.
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multi-phase project requiring systematic tracking across research, analysis, and writing stages.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="event_planning">
<user_message>Help me plan a team retreat - venue, agenda, catering, and send invitations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "venue_options", title: "Research and recommend venues", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "draft_agenda", title: "Create retreat agenda", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "arrange_catering", title: "Coordinate catering options", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "send_invites", title: "Draft and send invitations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multiple distinct deliverables with dependencies requiring organized tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="document_analysis">
<user_message>Review this 30-page contract for key terms, risks, and negotiation points.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "extract_key_terms", title: "Identify key contractual terms", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "flag_risks", title: "Flag potential risks and liabilities", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "negotiation_points", title: "Compile negotiation recommendations", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "summary_doc", title: "Prepare executive summary", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Substantial analysis work requiring methodical breakdown and systematic review.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="multiple_deliverables">
<user_message>I need: 1) competitor analysis for three companies, 2) SWOT analysis, 3) market positioning recommendations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "competitor_research", title: "Research three competitor companies", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "swot_analysis", title: "Develop SWOT analysis", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "positioning_recs", title: "Create market positioning recommendations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>User provided numbered list of distinct deliverables requiring separate effort.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_simple_question">
<user_message>What's the difference between renewable and sustainable energy?</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides explanation directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Informational request with no actionable work to complete or track.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_quick_lookup">
<user_message>Find the population of Tokyo.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Searches and provides answer without task tracking.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single straightforward lookup completable immediately.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_trivial_task">
<user_message>Summarize this 2-paragraph email.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides summary directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single simple action requiring no breakdown or progress tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_single_action">
<user_message>Check if my flight is on time.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Performs lookup and reports status without task management.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>One-step action with immediate completion, no organizational benefit from tasks.</reasoning>
</example>

=== BEST PRACTICES ===

For task creation: use descriptive unique IDs reflecting the work, start first task as 'in-progress', batch initial creation with beginning work. For progress tracking: update status immediately upon completion, keep only one 'in-progress' task unless parallel work is natural, add follow-up tasks as they emerge. For task breakdown: aim for reasonably-scoped tasks, group related small actions into logical units, split tasks requiring different approaches.

When uncertain whether to use task management, err on the side of creating tasks. Proactive organization demonstrates thoroughness and ensures comprehensive work completion.

params.name: Scrambled Eggs Simulation
params.content:
# Scrambled Eggs Cooking Simulation

## Initial State

### Kitchen Items
- Refrigerator (closed)
  - 12 raw eggs (in carton)
  - 1 stick of butter
- Cabinet
  - Salt shaker (full)
  - Pepper grinder (full)
- Drawer
  - 1 whisk (clean)
  - 1 spatula (clean)
- Stovetop
  - 1 frying pan (clean, on burner)
  - Burner (off)
- Counter
  - 1 mixing bowl (clean)
  - 1 plate (clean)

## Action Log

### Task 1: Gather ingredients
- **Action**: Open refrigerator
- **Action**: Take out 2 eggs from carton
- **Action**: Take out butter stick
- **Action**: Close refrigerator
- **Action**: Place eggs and butter on counter
- **Action**: Get salt shaker from cabinet
- **Action**: Get pepper grinder from cabinet
- **State Update**: 
  - Counter now has: 2 raw eggs, butter stick, salt shaker, pepper grinder, mixing bowl, plate

### Task 2: Get equipment
- **Action**: Open drawer
- **Action**: Take out whisk
- **Action**: Take out spatula
- **Action**: Close drawer
- **State Update**: 
  - Counter now has: whisk, spatula (in addition to previous items)
  - All equipment ready

### Task 3: Crack eggs into bowl and whisk
- **Action**: Pick up first egg
- **Action**: Crack egg on edge of bowl
- **Action**: Pour egg contents into bowl
- **Action**: Discard shell
- **Action**: Pick up second egg
- **Action**: Crack egg on edge of bowl
- **Action**: Pour egg contents into bowl
- **Action**: Discard shell
- **Action**: Add pinch of salt to bowl
- **Action**: Add grind of pepper to bowl
- **Action**: Pick up whisk
- **Action**: Whisk eggs for 30 seconds until well combined
- **State Update**: 
  - Bowl contains: 2 whisked raw eggs with salt and pepper
  - 2 eggshells discarded

### Task 4: Heat pan with butter
- **Action**: Turn stovetop burner to medium heat
- **Action**: Cut small piece of butter (about 1 tablespoon)
- **Action**: Place butter in frying pan
- **Action**: Wait for butter to melt and start sizzling (30 seconds)
- **State Update**: 
  - Frying pan: hot, with melted butter
  - Burner: on medium heat

### Task 5: Pour eggs into pan and scramble
- **Action**: Pick up bowl with whisked eggs
- **Action**: Pour egg mixture into hot pan with melted butter
- **Action**: Put down empty bowl
- **Action**: Pick up spatula
- **Action**: Wait 10 seconds for eggs to start setting
- **Action**: Gently stir eggs with spatula, pushing from edges to center
- **Action**: Continue stirring and folding eggs for 2-3 minutes
- **Action**: Remove pan from heat when eggs are just set but still creamy
- **State Update**: 
  - Frying pan contains: scrambled eggs (cooked)
  - Bowl: empty, with egg residue

### Task 6: Plate scrambled eggs
- **Action**: Pick up plate
- **Action**: Hold plate near pan
- **Action**: Use spatula to transfer scrambled eggs from pan to plate
- **Action**: Set down spatula
- **Action**: Turn off stovetop burner
- **State Update**: 
  - Plate: contains hot scrambled eggs
  - Frying pan: empty, with butter/egg residue
  - Burner: off

## Final State

### Kitchen Items
- Counter
  - 1 plate with scrambled eggs (ready to eat)
  - 1 mixing bowl (used, with egg residue)
  - 1 whisk (used)
  - 1 spatula (used)
  - Salt shaker (used)
  - Pepper grinder (used)
  - Butter stick (partially used)
- Stovetop
  - 1 frying pan (used, with residue)
  - Burner (off)
- Refrigerator
  - 10 raw eggs remaining in carton
- Trash
  - 2 eggshells

## Summary
Successfully prepared scrambled eggs following all planned tasks. The eggs are now plated and ready to serve. Total time: approximately 10 minutes.

tools.name: update-tasks
tools.description:
TASK MANAGEMENT TOOL - USAGE GUIDELINES

This tool maintains an organized task list during work sessions to track progress, break down objectives, and ensure thoroughness. After creating initial tasks, update them silently without announcing changes to the user.

=== CORE USAGE PRINCIPLES ===

Create and manage tasks for: multi-step objectives requiring 3+ distinct actions, complex projects needing careful sequencing, user requests for task organization, multiple deliverables provided together, new instructions (capture as tasks immediately with new IDs), completed work (mark done and add follow-ups), and active work (mark as 'in-progress', limit one at a time).

Skip task management for: single straightforward actions, simple requests achievable in 1-2 steps, informational queries, quick lookups or clarifications, and avoid creating verification tasks unless requested.

=== TOOL SPECIFICATION ===

update-tasks requires an array of task objects. Each task object contains:
- id (string, required): unique identifier like "task_1" or "research_sources"
- title (string, optional): update to clarify or refine task description
- status (string, optional): 'todo' | 'in-progress' | 'done'

Task status meanings: 'todo' means not yet started, 'in-progress' means currently being worked on, 'done' means completed successfully.

=== OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES ===

Update tasks in real-time as work progresses. Mark tasks 'done' immediately upon completion. Maintain only ONE task with 'in-progress' status at a time. Complete current tasks before starting new ones. Use specific, actionable task titles. Break complex work into manageable logical pieces. Batch task updates with other actions when possible for efficiency.

=== USAGE EXAMPLES ===

<example type="research_project">
<user_message>I need to research sustainable packaging options and write a report comparing costs and environmental impact.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "research_materials", title: "Research sustainable packaging materials", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "compare_costs", title: "Compile cost comparison data", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "assess_impact", title: "Evaluate environmental impact metrics", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "draft_report", title: "Write comparative analysis report", status: "todo"}

Begins research work immediately in same response.
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multi-phase project requiring systematic tracking across research, analysis, and writing stages.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="event_planning">
<user_message>Help me plan a team retreat - venue, agenda, catering, and send invitations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "venue_options", title: "Research and recommend venues", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "draft_agenda", title: "Create retreat agenda", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "arrange_catering", title: "Coordinate catering options", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "send_invites", title: "Draft and send invitations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Multiple distinct deliverables with dependencies requiring organized tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="document_analysis">
<user_message>Review this 30-page contract for key terms, risks, and negotiation points.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "extract_key_terms", title: "Identify key contractual terms", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "flag_risks", title: "Flag potential risks and liabilities", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "negotiation_points", title: "Compile negotiation recommendations", status: "todo"}
4. {id: "summary_doc", title: "Prepare executive summary", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Substantial analysis work requiring methodical breakdown and systematic review.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="multiple_deliverables">
<user_message>I need: 1) competitor analysis for three companies, 2) SWOT analysis, 3) market positioning recommendations.</user_message>
<assistant_action>
Creates tasks:
1. {id: "competitor_research", title: "Research three competitor companies", status: "in-progress"}
2. {id: "swot_analysis", title: "Develop SWOT analysis", status: "todo"}
3. {id: "positioning_recs", title: "Create market positioning recommendations", status: "todo"}
</assistant_action>
<reasoning>User provided numbered list of distinct deliverables requiring separate effort.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_simple_question">
<user_message>What's the difference between renewable and sustainable energy?</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides explanation directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Informational request with no actionable work to complete or track.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_quick_lookup">
<user_message>Find the population of Tokyo.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Searches and provides answer without task tracking.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single straightforward lookup completable immediately.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_trivial_task">
<user_message>Summarize this 2-paragraph email.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Provides summary directly without creating tasks.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>Single simple action requiring no breakdown or progress tracking.</reasoning>
</example>

<example type="skip_single_action">
<user_message>Check if my flight is on time.</user_message>
<assistant_action>Performs lookup and reports status without task management.</assistant_action>
<reasoning>One-step action with immediate completion, no organizational benefit from tasks.</reasoning>
</example>

=== BEST PRACTICES ===

For task creation: use descriptive unique IDs reflecting the work, start first task as 'in-progress', batch initial creation with beginning work. For progress tracking: update status immediately upon completion, keep only one 'in-progress' task unless parallel work is natural, add follow-up tasks as they emerge. For task breakdown: aim for reasonably-scoped tasks, group related small actions into logical units, split tasks requiring different approaches.

When uncertain whether to use task management, err on the side of creating tasks. Proactive organization demonstrates thoroughness and ensures comprehensive work completion.
